Michael Stack wrote:
> 
> 
> Frank McCown wrote:
>  >
>  > > The question is, how much control will Heritrix give me when running
>  > > it from the command line? I saw in the FAQ that there is a "cmdline
>  > > control utility". Can I launch the tool from a script and then be
>  > > notified that a crawl job has successfully completed? If the crawler
>  > > is stuck in a crawler trap or if I just want to see what is left in
>  > > the crawl frontier, can I launch the WUI to check on the status in the
>  > > middle of the crawl?
>  >
>  > Sorry for any misunderstanding. I am aware of all the issues regarding
>  > how Heritrix can limit download size, delay, etc. in comparison to wget.
>  > My question is regarding the command line issues as stated above.
>  >
> 
> Hey Frank (We met at IWAW05):
> 
> Here is a FAQ on command-line control of Heritrix:
> http://crawler.archive.org/faq.html#cmdlinecontrol. 
> <http://crawler.archive.org/faq.html#cmdlinecontrol.> It points to a
> simple tool we wrote that talks to remote Heritrix instances by
> launching a JVM to send JMX queries. Because the command-line tool
> lives only for the life of the sending of the JMX message and receipt of
> response from the crawler, it won't be around to catch the notifications
> emitted by Heritrix at key points during the life of a crawl. You could
> use the little command-line tool to poll on a period asking 'are you
> finished yet?' (Or write code to register for notifications and then act
> on the events you are interested in).
> 
> Regards the WUI, its either on or off. We've not added tools to
> enable/disable the WUIR midcrawl. Why not launch with it enabled? Or
> you could also use the aforementioned command-line tool to get text
> versions of the reports the WUI exposes on state of frontier, etc., and
> perhaps go without the WUI altogether... though I wouldn't recommend it
> until you'd first established familiarity with running crawls in
> Heritrix. The command-line output might in places assume previous
> familiarity with the WUI presentation.
> 
> St.Ack


Thanks for the info, Michael!  I appreciate your help.  I'll be giving 
Heritrix a try in the next few days.

Frank
